block.p: HAITI: VOTE PROTESTS -- Supporters of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide blocked downtown Port-au-Prince, burning tires and stoning cars to demand results from local and legislative elections held May 21. Preliminary results showed Mr. Aristide's Lavalas Family party winning 16 of 17 Senate seats and more than 20 seats in the 83-member House of Deputies. An official said final results had been given to the electoral council, but no reason has been given for the delay in their publication.

ARGENTINA: CRIME-FIGHTING ACCORDS -- Justice and interior ministers from six South American nations meeting in Buenos Aires agreed to share more information to fight organized crime. Ministers from Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay signed eight accords to share information regarding missing children, illegal movement of radioactive products, and joint police training to fight drugs.

BRITAIN: SHOTS ON ROYAL TRAIN -- A bodyguard in the elite Royalty and Diplomatic Protection Squad fired two shots in the staff dining room of the Royal Train as the queen and Prince Philip slept two carriages away during an overnight stay in Wales. One shot lodged in the floor, the second in a table. The police said they were treating the episode as an accident. The unidentified officer was relieved of his duties and returned to London pending an investigation.

KOSOVO: PARTIES REGISTER FOR VOTE -- Twenty-two political parties and a coalition of six more registered by the deadline to contest local elections planned in October, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said. Coming only 16 months after the United Nations took over the running of the Serbian province after a NATO bombing campaign had expelled Yugoslav forces, the elections are intended to set Kosovo back on the road to democracy.

CHECHNYA: NEW VIOLENCE -- Guerrilla violence claimed new victims as gunmen shot and killed a moderate Muslim cleric, and the bodies of two beheaded Russian police officers were found with the bodies of two Chechen civilians. The cleric was described as an opponent of fundamentalists among the rebels. Ambush attacks against federal forces and their civilian supporters have stepped up recently.

LIECHTENSTEIN: BANK RAIDED -- A bank owned by the family of the ruling prince, Hans-Adam II, has been raided by agents tracking possible money laundering, the police said. Twenty police officers from Liechtenstein and neighboring Austria seized documents and electronic data from L.G.T. Bank. A six-month investigation has rocked the Alpine principality. Eight people have been arrested since May.

MYANMAR: PRESSED ON FORCED LABOR -- The International Labor Organization has voted to open the way for Myanmar to be sanctioned for its apparently widespread use of forced labor. In a compromise between Western countries urging rapid action and Asian nations siding with Myanmar, no measures would take effect until Nov. 30. The agency's resolution asks other member countries to review their links with Myanmar and take steps to ensure it ''cannot take advantage of such relations to perpetuate or extend the system of forced or compulsory labor.''

TAIWAN: WORKWEEK CUT -- The Legislature passed a bill to cut weekly hours for blue-collar workers from 48 to 42, despite fierce opposition by owners of labor-intensive industries. The measure, to take effect in January, will add 7.5 percent to business costs in terms of overtime pay, officials said. Blue-collar workers will be able to take a Saturday off every other week, a practice adopted two years ago by civil servants.

LEBANON: 29 ON TRIAL -- A military court began the trial of 29 people who are accused of planning attacks on American and Israeli targets in Jordan on the orders of Osama bin Laden. The trial in Beirut coincides with one of 28 suspects in Jordan on similar charges. The nationalities of the 29 men, 18 of whom are at large, were given as Lebanese, Palestinian and Syrian.

JORDAN: NEW PREMIER EXPECTED -- King Abdullah is expected to replace his conservative prime minister with a liberal-leaning successor with strong business credentials to push reforms, officials and diplomats said. They said Prime Minister Abdul al-Raouf al-Rawabdeh, appointed in March 1999 after Abdullah became king, was widely expected to be dismissed within days or weeks. His most likely successor is a legislator, Ali Abu al-Ragheb, above, said to be favored by business circles.

ZIMBABWE: CAMPAIGN VIOLENCE -- Thousands of villagers have fled their homes to escape a terror campaign that has made free and fair elections impossible, rights groups said. They said more than 13,000 rural people had sought refuge in towns and cities to escape political violence ahead of elections on June 24 and 25, and others had had their identity books seized and destroyed by pro-government militants. Tony Reeler, director of the Zimbabwe Human Rights Forum, said there had been a ''complete subversion of the democratic electoral process.''

ETHIOPIA: ELECTION VICTORY -- The governing Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front has won a landslide victory in general elections held last month, the National Election Board announced. Although elections have been delayed or are being re-run in parts of the country, the party has already won 467 of the 548 seats in the lower house of Parliament, results showed.
